Award.AwardTitle: Challenges and Opportunities in Scientific Data Discovery and Reuse in the Data Revolution: Harnessing the Power of AI

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The volume and heterogeneity of scientific data goes beyond a researcher?s ability to find relevant data, make different formats interoperable, and deal with difficult ontological and language issues. Progress requires bringing together experts in data curation with experts in Artificial Intelligence (AI) to begin a dialog and collaboration on AI tools to span the gap between data and its reuse. The PIs will organize the conference "Challenges and Opportunities in Scientific Data Discovery and Reuse in the Data Revolution: Harnessing the Power of AI"; the objective is to bring together diverse stakeholders including research librarians and data managers, the AI community, and users and consumers of scientific data to dialog around critical places in the data lifecycle where AI could be groundbreaking.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation?s Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the project Challenges and Opportunities in Scientific Data Discovery and Reuse in the Data Revolution: Harnessing the Power of AI, the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) and the Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Libraries organized a 2.5-day conference, AIDR 2019: Artificial Intelligence for Data Discovery and Reuse, to explore ways that artificial intelligence (AI) can be applied to improve scientific data discovery and reuse.

Approximately 150 individuals from 10 countries and 65 organizations participated, spanning academia, industry, government, and non-profit institutions. A single conference track promoted valuable interdisciplinary discussion by the attendees, who represented a wide variety of fields including computer, library, life, environmental, and natural sciences, humanities, ethics, cybersecurity, urban planning, and hardware and software engineering. Representatives of NSF XSEDE (Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment) service providers and public clouds also participated.

The AIDR 2019 conference was structured into five technical sessions (one per half day), including keynote presentations on May 13 and 14, nine invited presentations, twenty regular presentations, two panels, and a poster reception. The five technical sessions were as follows:

  • Automation in data curation and metadata generation
  • Automation in data discovery
  • Integrating datasets and enabling interoperability
  • Biomedical applications
  • Data security, privacy and algorithmic bias

The first panel, Challenges and Opportunities in Data Reuse Using the Power of AI, was strongly aligned with the focus of the conference. The second panel, Enabling Smart and Safe Communities Through AI, explored a specific, emerging application area.

Participants indicated that they found the conference to be highly successful. Peer-reviewed proceedings were published, and presentation slides and posters were also disseminated (see Broader Impacts, below).

Intellectual Merit

The scientific data available online today is vast, yet individual datasets are generally poorly described or not described at all, metadata is inconsistent or missing, standardization on ontologies is rare, and new data formats are constantly emerging. Substantial efforts have been made ? with varying degrees of success ? to store and share scientific data and related digital research output, yet those repositories are generally silos, lacking interoperability with complementary data other than by expert human data wrangling. The proliferation of data and data repositories creates an urgent need for machine learning (ML) and AI tools to help researchers find and work with data, especially domain specialists who are not computer scientists or data scientists.

The challenges of discovering and reusing data made available through unrelated frameworks, using different terminology and language, and distributed across resources globally go beyond what even accomplished data scientists can do in reasonable amounts of time. AI techniques have potential to augment domain and data scientists by allowing them more easily to discover and reuse complementary data in advancing the frontier of knowledge.

The AIDR 2019 conference addressed these areas to varying degrees and provided examples of what is already being done. The most active discussion areas centered on ethics (including data privacy) and community building.

Broader Impacts

Participation was strong for a first-year conference. The 150 individuals from 10 countries and 65 organizations spanned a very wide range of disciplines, and there was strong student participation.

Peer-reviewed proceedings were published in partnership with the Association of Computing Machinery (ACM) at https://dl.acm.org/doi/proceedings/10.1145/3359115. Presentations and posters were disseminated as the AIDR Collection on the F1000Research open publishing platform at https://f1000research.com/collections/aidr.

Awards were presented for Best Student Presentation and Best Student Poster Presentation. Two awards were presented for each, reflecting the high quality of the submissions.

Although application of AI for scientific data discovery and reuse is still in its infancy, the impact on society eventually will be tremendous. The ability to discover and reuse data from the many high-value, federally-funded datasets, as well as datasets created internationally, developed through citizen science, and contributed by the private sector, will amplify the value of all data by democratizing access and enabling interoperability.
